bibl.title: Lease between Robert Carter and Edmund Jenings, May 23, 1718

div1.p: Robert Carter leases property in Williamsburg from Edmund Jenings.

div1.head: Lease between Robert Carter and Edmund Jenings, May 23, 1718, for property in Williamsburg.
div1.p:
[T]his Indenture made the t[wen]ty third day of May in the Yeare [of our Lord 1718 between]
[E]dmund Jenings of Williamsburg[h] of the one part and Robert Carter o[f Lancaster County of the second part]
[f]or and in consideration of the sum of five shillings lawfull money to him in ha[nd paid]
[Rec]eipt whereof the said Edmund doth hereby acknowledge And thereof and [. . .]
[. . . ]d Admrs- by the present Hath granted bargained and sold and by these [presents grants]
[bargains] and Assigns All that One Messuage or Tenement of him the afforesaid Edmund [now?]
let in the Tenure or occapation of John Clayton situate standing and be[ing]
in the Citty of Williamsburgh between the now Dwelling house of the said Ed[mund and]
[that] purchased from Mary Whaley now in the Tenure or Occupation of the sa[id Robert]
[t]o the Street and on each side or End of the said house to witt to the Eastwa[rd]
Street parallel with that distance a strait direct Line South one quarte[r]
of the Towne in that part and West[war]d All the land to join to the land of the
of the Towne in that part And the [R]e[v]erion and REevercions Remainder a[nd]
[a]ll Rents and services reserved [...]all or any lease or leases of the pre[mises]
or Tenement land and premises [a]fforementioned and hereby intended [with?]
privileges and appurtenances Un[to] the said Robert Carter his Exrs and A[dmrs]
[. . .] thence next ensuing and fully [t] be compleat and ended To the [E . . . ]
[. . .]ses and may be enabled to [. . .] accept of a Grant & Release [. . . ]
[In] witne3ss whereiof the parties to these presents Interchangeably have sett [their hands]
[and seals]
E Jenings
[At a court] for James City County the 9th of June 1718
[the parties ca]me into Court presented & acknowledged this Lease to
[be correct &] it is admitted to Record
Test
WilRobertson ClCor

div1.head: NOTES
div1.note: Source copy consulted: Carter Family Papers, 1667-1862, Record Series Number: 01/Mss. 39.1 C24, Special Collections Research Center Earl Gregg Swem Library, College of William and Mary The sheet bearig this document has been damaged on both the right and left sides and portions of the text lost. The document, in the hand of an unidentified clerk, bears the signature and seal of Edmund Jenings as well as the signature of the clerk of the James City County court clerk, William Robertson, who has entered the authentication at the end of the document. The present editor has been greatly assisted in the transcription of this document by an earlier "transcription prepared by G. H. Reese and M. G. McGregor of Colonial Williamsburg's Research Department."
[1] A messuage is "the portion of land intended to be occupied, or actually occupied, as a site for a dwelling-house and its appurtenances." (Oxford English Dictionary)

[2] "In 1706 Mrs. Mary Whaley established, in honor of her little son Matthew, a school in Bruton parish, York county, near Williamsburg, above York-Hampton parish, which she called Matteys School. She gave to the school ten acres of land. . . . In 1741-42, Mrs. Whaley, dying in England, left to the school a legacy of fifty pounds and the residue of her estate after payment of legacies. This particular sum, however, was not realized till a hundred years later." (Lyon Gardiner Tyler, "Education in Colonial Virginia: Part III. Free Schools." William and Mary Quarterly. 6(October 1897): 70-85.)
[3] Teste is a Latin word used in legal documents "in the authenticating clause of a writ . . . before [or after] the name of a person cited as witness or authority." (Oxford English Dictionary)
